column39: Wives of Acting Governor and another senior portugese official

column17: This incident occurred 43 miles outside of Hong Kong.
column18: 05/01/1998: A remote bomb detonated under the car belonging to Judiciary Police Director Dr. Antonio Marques Baptista as he approached it near Hong Kong, China. The explosion caused damage to the car but no casualties. No group claimed credit for the attack which was believed to be in response to a crackdown on the Triad criminal organization.
column39: Judiciary Police Director Dr. Antonio Marques Baptista near Hong Kong, China
column64: The bomb was an attempted assassination and meant to intimidate the police division tasked with stopping organized crime.
column108: One government-owned Mitsubishi Spacewagon was destroyed in the attack.
column125: This attack followed a week of triad-related raids and arrests of suspected gangland members.
column126: Harold, Bruning, ï¿½Macao Police Arrest Alleged Triad Leader,ï¿½ Hong Kong Standard, May 2, 1998.
column127: Adam Lee, ï¿½Bomb Destroys Macao Police Chief Car,ï¿½ Hong Kong South China Morning Post, May 2, 1998.

column18: 05/08/1998: A number of Molotov cocktails were thrown at a number of vehicles and motorcycles in Macau, China. The attacks, which occurred within a two-hour period, damaged 14 vehicles and 8 motorcycles, but caused no injuries. Two shops were also affected by the fire but suffered only minor damage. The group 14 K Triad was suspected in the attack.
column39: Vehicles and Motorcycles in Macau, China
column64: Several motives for the attacks have been posed: 1) an act of revenge by the followers of alleged 14 K triad leader Wan Kuok-koi for his pre-trial detention; 2) 14 K Triad's response to the Macau government's decision to ban the release of the movie Casino; 3) a rival faction of 14K Triad flexing its muscles.
column108: Fourteen vehicles and eight motorcycles were damaged or destroyed. Two stores were slightly damaged.
column125: This was one of four related attacks (cf. 199805110001-03; 199805080002). Local media reportedly received anonymous phone calls the day of the attacks claiming that 100 vehicles would be burned in response to the pre-trial detention of Wan. Edmund Ho, who was expected to be Macau's first chief executive in 1999, reportedly owned one of the shops damaged in this attack.
column126: Harald Bruning, ï¿½Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,ï¿½ Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
column127: ï¿½Further Fire Bomb Attacks in Macao,ï¿½ Hong Kong RTHK Radio 4, May 8, 1998.
column128: ï¿½Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,ï¿½ Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.

column18: 05/11/1998: A private car was set ablaze on Avenida de Horta e Costa about 3:30 am in Macau, China. The blaze, which was quickly extinguished by firemen, caused no injuries. The attack was part of a wave of similar attacks, believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
column64: Several motives for the attacks have been posed: 1) an act of revenge by the followers of alleged 14 K triad leader Wan Kuok-koi for his pre-trial detention; 2) 14 K Triad's response to the Macau government's decision to ban the release of the movie Casino; 3) a rival faction of 14K Triad flexing its muscles.
column108: One privately owned vehicle was damaged by fire.
column126: Harald Bruning, ï¿½Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,ï¿½ Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
column127: ï¿½Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,ï¿½ Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.
column128: Harald Bruning, ï¿½Police Raid 'Firebomb Factory' Amid Arson Attacks,ï¿½ Hong Kong Standard, May 12, 1998.

column18: 05/11/1998: One hour following a similar attack on a private vehicle, three cars and 15 motorcycles parked on Avenida de Venceslau de Morais in Macau, China were set ablaze. The attack was part of a wave of similar attacks, believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
column39: Vehicles and Motorcycles in Macau, China
column64: Several motives for the attacks have been posed: 1) an act of revenge by the followers of alleged 14 K triad leader Wan Kuok-koi for his pre-trial detention; 2) 14 K Triad's response to the Macau government's decision to ban the release of the movie Casino; 3) a rival faction of 14K Triad flexing its muscles.
column108: Three vehicles and 15 motorcycles were damaged or destroyed.

column18: 05/11/1998: Following the arrest of eight suspects related to a string of similar attacks, a motorcycle was set ablaze near the Lan Heung Hok restaurant in Macau, China. There were no casualties reported. The attack was believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
column64: Several motives for the attacks have been posed: 1) an act of revenge by the followers of alleged 14 K triad leader Wan Kuok-koi for his pre-trial detention; 2) 14 K Triad's response to the Macau government's decision to ban the release of the movie Casino; 3) a rival faction of 14K Triad flexing its muscles.
column108: One motorcycle was destroyed in the incident.
column126: Harald Bruning, ï¿½Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,ï¿½ Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.

column18: 09/08/1998: Fifteen people were injured in Macau, China, when an explosion went off on a parked motorcycle. The explosion was detonated as policemen and journalists crowded around the scene of a car bomb, which had gone off 20 minutes earlier. No one was killed, and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
column126: ï¿½Bomb blasts injure 14 in Macau violence,ï¿½ Agence France Presse, September 8, 1998.
column127: 15 injured in Macau triad bomb trap,ï¿½ South China Morning Post, September 9, 1998.
